doc.name: M:PeterO.ExtendedFloat.ToDouble
doc.summary:
Converts this value to a 64-bit floating-point number. The half-even rounding mode is used.
If this value is a NaN, sets the high bit of the 64-bit floating point number's mantissa for a quiet NaN, and clears it for a signaling NaN. Then the next highest bit of the mantissa is cleared for a quiet NaN, and set for a signaling NaN. Then the other bits of the mantissa are set to the lowest bits of this object's unsigned mantissa.
doc.returns: The closest 64-bit floating-point number to this value. The return value can be positive infinity or negative infinity if this value exceeds the range of a 64-bit floating point number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.ExtendedFloat.ToEngineeringString
doc.summary: Converts this value to an extended decimal, then returns the value of that decimal's ToEngineeringString method.
doc.returns: A text string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.ExtendedFloat.ToExtendedDecimal
doc.summary: Converts this value to an extended decimal.
doc.returns: An extended decimal with the same value as this extended float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.ExtendedFloat.ToPlainString
doc.summary: Converts this value to a string, but without exponential notation.
doc.returns: A text string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.ExtendedFloat.ToSingle
doc.summary:
Converts this value to a 32-bit floating-point number. The half-even rounding mode is used.
If this value is a NaN, sets the high bit of the 32-bit floating point number's mantissa for a quiet NaN, and clears it for a signaling NaN. Then the next highest bit of the mantissa is cleared for a quiet NaN, and set for a signaling NaN. Then the other bits of the mantissa are set to the lowest bits of this object's unsigned mantissa.
doc.returns: The closest 32-bit floating-point number to this value. The return value can be positive infinity or negative infinity if this value exceeds the range of a 32-bit floating point number.

doc.name: T:PeterO.ExtendedRational
doc.summary:
Arbitrary-precision rational number. This class cannot be inherited; this is a change in version 2.0 from previous versions, where the class was inadvertently left inheritable.
Thread safety:Instances of this class are immutable, so they are inherently safe for use by multiple threads. Multiple instances of this object with the same properties are interchangeable, so they should not be compared using the "==" operator (which only checks if each side of the operator is the same instance).

doc.summary: Converts this rational number to a decimal number, but if the result would have a nonterminating decimal expansion, rounds that result to the given precision.

If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.AdjustExponent
doc.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the EMax and EMin properties refer to the number's Exponent property adjusted to the number's precision, or just the number's Exponent property. The default value is true, meaning that EMax and EMin refer to the adjusted exponent. Setting this value to false (using WithAdjustExponent) is useful for modeling floating point representations with an integer mantissa and an integer exponent, such as Java's BigDecimal.
doc.value: True if the EMax and EMin properties refer to the number's Exponent property adjusted to the number's precision, or false if they refer to just the number's Exponent property.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Basic
doc.summary: Basic precision context, 9 digits precision, rounding mode half-up, unlimited exponent range. The default rounding mode is HalfUp.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.BigDecimalJava
doc.summary: Precision context for Java's BigDecimal format. The default rounding mode is HalfUp.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Binary128
doc.summary: Precision context for the IEEE-754-2008 binary128 format, 113 bits precision. The default rounding mode is HalfEven.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Binary16
doc.summary: Precision context for the IEEE-754-2008 binary16 format, 11 bits precision. The default rounding mode is HalfEven.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Binary32
doc.summary: Precision context for the IEEE-754-2008 binary32 format, 24 bits precision. The default rounding mode is HalfEven.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Binary64
doc.summary: Precision context for the IEEE-754-2008 binary64 format, 53 bits precision. The default rounding mode is HalfEven.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.ClampNormalExponents
doc.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a converted number's Exponent property will not be higher than EMax + 1 - Precision. If a number's exponent is higher than that value, but not high enough to cause overflow, the exponent is clamped to that value and enough zeros are added to the number's mantissa to account for the adjustment. If HasExponentRange is false, this value is always false.
doc.value: If true, a converted number's Exponent property will not be higher than EMax + 1 - Precision.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.CliDecimal
doc.summary: Precision context for the Common Language Infrastructure (.NET Framework) decimal format, 96 bits precision, and a valid exponent range of -28 to 0. The default rounding mode is HalfEven.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Copy
doc.summary: Initializes a new PrecisionContext that is a copy of another PrecisionContext.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Decimal128
doc.summary: Precision context for the IEEE-754-2008 decimal128 format. The default rounding mode is HalfEven.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Decimal32
doc.summary: Precision context for the IEEE-754-2008 decimal32 format. The default rounding mode is HalfEven.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Decimal64
doc.summary: Precision context for the IEEE-754-2008 decimal64 format. The default rounding mode is HalfEven.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.EMax
doc.summary: Gets the highest exponent possible when a converted number is expressed in scientific notation with one digit before the decimal point. For example, with a precision of 3 and an EMax of 100, the maximum value possible is 9.99E + 100. (This is not the same as the highest possible Exponent property.) If HasExponentRange is false, this value will be 0.
doc.value: The highest exponent possible when a converted number is expressed in scientific notation with one digit before the decimal point. For example, with a precision of 3 and an EMax of 100, the maximum value possible is 9.99E + 100. (This is not the same as the highest possible Exponent property.) If HasExponentRange is false, this value will be 0.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.EMin
doc.summary: Gets the lowest exponent possible when a converted number is expressed in scientific notation with one digit before the decimal point. For example, with a precision of 3 and an EMin of -100, the next value that comes after 0 is 0.001E-100. (If AdjustExponent is false, this property specifies the lowest possible Exponent property instead.) If HasExponentRange is false, this value will be 0.
doc.value: The lowest exponent possible when a converted number is expressed in scientific notation with one digit before the decimal point.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.ExponentWithinRange(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger)
doc.summary: Determines whether a number can have the given Exponent property under this precision context.
doc.param: An arbitrary-precision integer indicating the desired exponent.
doc.returns: True if a number can have the given Exponent property under this precision context; otherwise, false. If this context allows unlimited precision, returns true for the exponent EMax and any exponent less than EMax.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.FlagClamped
doc.summary: Signals that the exponent was adjusted to fit the exponent range.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.FlagDivideByZero
doc.summary: Signals a division of a nonzero number by zero.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.FlagInexact
doc.summary: Signals that the result was rounded to a different mathematical value, but as close as possible to the original.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.FlagInvalid
doc.summary: Signals an invalid operation.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.FlagLostDigits
doc.summary: Signals that an operand was rounded to a different mathematical value before an operation.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.FlagOverflow
doc.summary: Signals that the result is non-zero and the exponent is higher than the highest exponent allowed.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.FlagRounded
F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.FlagSubnormal
doc.summary: Signals that the result's exponent, before rounding, is lower than the lowest exponent allowed.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.FlagUnderflow
doc.summary: Signals that the result's exponent, before rounding, is lower than the lowest exponent allowed, and the result was rounded to a different mathematical value, but as close as possible to the original.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Flags
doc.summary: Gets or sets the flags that are set from converting numbers according to this precision context. If HasFlags is false, this value will be 0. This value is a combination of bit fields. To retrieve a particular flag, use the AND operation on the return value of this method. For example: (this.Flags & PrecisionContext.FlagInexact) != 0 returns TRUE if the Inexact flag is set.
doc.value: The flags that are set from converting numbers according to this precision context. If HasFlags is false, this value will be 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.ForPrecision(System.Int32)
doc.summary: Creates a new precision context using the given maximum number of digits, an unlimited exponent range, and the HalfUp rounding mode.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.ForPrecisionAndRounding(System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary: Creates a new PrecisionContext object initialized with an unlimited exponent range, and the given rounding mode and maximum precision.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.ForRounding(PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary: Creates a new PrecisionContext object initialized with an unlimited precision, an unlimited exponent range, and the given rounding mode.
doc.param: The rounding mode for the new precision context.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.HasExponentRange
doc.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this context defines a minimum and maximum exponent. If false, converted exponents can have any exponent and operations can't cause overflow or underflow.
doc.value: True if this context defines a minimum and maximum exponent; otherwise, false.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.HasFlags
doc.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this context has a mutable Flags field.
doc.value: True if this context has a mutable Flags field; otherwise, false.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.HasMaxPrecision
doc.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this context defines a maximum precision.
doc.value: True if this context defines a maximum precision; otherwise, false.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.IsPrecisionInBits
doc.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this context's Precision property is in bits, rather than digits. The default is false.
doc.value: True if this context's Precision property is in bits, rather than digits; otherwise, false. The default is false.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.IsSimplified
doc.summary: Gets a value indicating whether to use a "simplified" arithmetic. In the simplified arithmetic, infinity, not-a-number, and subnormal numbers are not allowed, and negative zero is treated the same as positive zero. For further details, see http://speleotrove.com/decimal/dax3274.html
doc.value: True if a "simplified" arithmetic will be used; otherwise, false.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Precision
doc.summary: Gets the maximum length of a converted number in digits, ignoring the decimal point and exponent. For example, if precision is 3, a converted number's mantissa can range from 0 to 999 (up to three digits long). If 0, converted numbers can have any precision.
doc.value: The maximum length of a converted number in digits, ignoring the decimal point and exponent.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Rounding
doc.summary: Gets the desired rounding mode when converting numbers that can't be represented in the given precision and exponent range.
doc.value: The desired rounding mode when converting numbers that can't be represented in the given precision and exponent range.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.ToString
doc.summary: Gets a string representation of this object. Note that the format is not intended to be parsed and may change at any time.
doc.returns: A string representation of this object.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Traps
doc.summary:
Gets the traps that are set for each flag in the context. Whenever a flag is signaled, even if HasFlags is false, and the flag's trap is enabled, the operation will throw a TrapException.
For example, if Traps equals FlagInexact and FlagSubnormal, a TrapException will be thrown if an operation's return value is not the same as the exact result (FlagInexact) or if the return value's exponent is lower than the lowest allowed (FlagSubnormal).
doc.value: The traps that are set for each flag in the context.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.Unlimited
doc.summary: No specific limit on precision. Rounding mode HalfUp.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithAdjustExponent(System.Boolean)
doc.summary: Copies this PrecisionContext and sets the copy's "AdjustExponent" property to the given value.
doc.param: The parameter is not documented yet.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithBigExponentRange(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EInteger)
doc.summary: Copies this precision context and sets the copy's exponent range.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithBigPrecision(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger)
doc.summary: Copies this PrecisionContext and gives it a particular precision value.
doc.param: The parameter is not documented yet.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithBlankFlags
doc.summary: Copies this PrecisionContext with HasFlags set to true and a Flags value of 0.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithExponentClamp(System.Boolean)
doc.summary: Copies this precision context and sets the copy's "ClampNormalExponents" flag to the given value.
doc.param: The parameter is not documented yet.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithExponentRange(System.Int32,System.Int32)
doc.summary: Copies this precision context and sets the copy's exponent range.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithNoFlags
doc.summary: Copies this PrecisionContext with HasFlags set to false and a Flags value of 0.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithPrecision(System.Int32)
doc.summary: Copies this PrecisionContext and gives it a particular precision value.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithPrecisionInBits(System.Boolean)
doc.summary: Copies this PrecisionContext and sets the copy's "IsPrecisionInBits" property to the given value.
doc.param: The parameter is not documented yet.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithRounding(PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary: Copies this PrecisionContext with the specified rounding mode.
doc.param: The parameter is not documented yet.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithSimplified(System.Boolean)
doc.summary: Copies this PrecisionContext and sets the copy's "IsSimplified" property to the given value.
doc.param: The parameter is not documented yet.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithTraps(System.Int32)
doc.summary: Copies this PrecisionContext with Traps set to the given value.
doc.param: Flags representing the traps to enable. See the property "Traps".
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EContext.WithUnlimitedExponents
doc.summary: Copies this PrecisionContext with an unlimited exponent range.
doc.returns: A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.

doc.name: T:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal
doc.summary:
Represents an arbitrary-precision decimal floating-point number.
About decimal arithmetic
Decimal (base-10) arithmetic, such as that provided by this class, is appropriate for calculations involving such real-world data as prices and other sums of money, tax rates, and measurements. These calculations often involve multiplying or dividing one decimal with another decimal, or performing other operations on decimal numbers. Many of these calculations also rely on rounding behavior in which the result after rounding is a decimal number (for example, multiplying a price by a premium rate, then rounding, should result in a decimal amount of money).
On the other hand, most implementations of float and double, including in C# and Java, store numbers in a binary (base-2) floating-point format and use binary floating-point arithmetic. Many decimal numbers can't be represented exactly in binary floating-point format (regardless of its length). Applying binary arithmetic to numbers intended to be decimals can sometimes lead to unintuitive results, as is shown in the description for the FromDouble() method of this class.
About EDecimal instances
Each instance of this class consists of an integer mantissa and an integer exponent, both arbitrary-precision. The value of the number equals mantissa * 10^exponent.
The mantissa is the value of the digits that make up a number, ignoring the decimal point and exponent. For example, in the number 2356.78, the mantissa is 235678. The exponent is where the "floating" decimal point of the number is located. A positive exponent means "move it to the right", and a negative exponent means "move it to the left." In the example 2, 356.78, the exponent is -2, since it has 2 decimal places and the decimal point is "moved to the left by 2." Therefore, in the arbitrary-precision decimal representation, this number would be stored as 235678 * 10^-2.
The mantissa and exponent format preserves trailing zeros in the number's value. This may give rise to multiple ways to store the same value. For example, 1.00 and 1 would be stored differently, even though they have the same value. In the first case, 100 * 10^-2 (100 with decimal point moved left by 2), and in the second case, 1 * 10^0 (1 with decimal point moved 0).
This class also supports values for negative zero, not-a-number (NaN) values, and infinity. Negative zero is generally used when a negative number is rounded to 0; it has the same mathematical value as positive zero. Infinity is generally used when a non-zero number is divided by zero, or when a very high number can't be represented in a given exponent range. Not-a-number is generally used to signal errors.
This class implements the General Decimal Arithmetic Specification version 1.70 (except part of chapter 6): http://speleotrove.com/decimal/decarith.html
Errors and Exceptions
Passing a signaling NaN to any arithmetic operation shown here will signal the flag FlagInvalid and return a quiet NaN, even if another operand to that operation is a quiet NaN, unless noted otherwise.
Passing a quiet NaN to any arithmetic operation shown here will return a quiet NaN, unless noted otherwise. Invalid operations will also return a quiet NaN, as stated in the individual methods.
Unless noted otherwise, passing a null arbitrary-precision decimal argument to any method here will throw an exception.
When an arithmetic operation signals the flag FlagInvalid, FlagOverflow, or FlagDivideByZero, it will not throw an exception too, unless the flag's trap is enabled in the precision context (see EContext's Traps property).
If an operation requires creating an intermediate value that might be too big to fit in memory (or might require more than 2 gigabytes of memory to store -- due to the current use of a 32-bit integer internally as a length), the operation may signal an invalid-operation flag and return not-a-number (NaN). In certain rare cases, the CompareTo method may throw OutOfMemoryException (called OutOfMemoryError in Java) in the same circumstances.
Serialization
An arbitrary-precision decimal value can be serialized (converted to a stable format) in one of the following ways:
By calling the toString() method, which will always return distinct strings for distinct arbitrary-precision decimal values.
By calling the UnsignedMantissa, Exponent, and IsNegative properties, and calling the IsInfinity, IsQuietNaN, and IsSignalingNaN methods. The return values combined will uniquely identify a particular arbitrary-precision decimal value.
Thread safety
Instances of this class are immutable, so they are inherently safe for use by multiple threads. Multiple instances of this object with the same properties are interchangeable, so they should not be compared using the "==" operator (which only checks if each side of the operator is the same instance).
Comparison considerations
This class's natural ordering (under the CompareTo method) is not consistent with the Equals method. This means that two values that compare as equal under the CompareTo method might not be equal under the Equals method. The CompareTo method compares the mathematical values of the two instances passed to it (and considers two different NaN values as equal), while two instances with the same mathematical value, but different exponents, will be considered unequal under the Equals method.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Abs
doc.summary: Gets the absolute value of this object.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Abs(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the absolute value of this object (if it's negative, it becomes positive).
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: The absolute value of this object.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Add(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal)
doc.summary: Adds this object and another decimal number and returns the result.
doc.returns: The sum of the two objects.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Add(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the sum of this object and another object. The result's exponent is set to the lower of the exponents of the two operands.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: The sum of thisValue and the other object.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.CompareTo(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal)
doc.summary:
Compares the mathematical values of this object and another object, accepting NaN values.
This method is not consistent with the Equals method because two different numbers with the same mathematical value, but different exponents, will compare as equal.
In this method, negative zero and positive zero are considered equal.
If this object or the other object is a quiet NaN or signaling NaN, this method will not trigger an error. Instead, NaN will compare greater than any other number, including infinity. Two different NaN values will be considered equal.
doc.returns: Less than 0 if this object's value is less than the other value, or greater than 0 if this object's value is greater than the other value or if is null, or 0 if both values are equal.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.CompareToBinary(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)
doc.summary: Compares an arbitrary-precision binary float with this instance.
doc.param: The other object to compare. Can be null.
doc.returns: Zero if the values are equal; a negative number if this instance is less, or a positive number if this instance is greater. Returns 0 if both values are NaN (even signaling NaN) and 1 if this value is NaN (even signaling NaN) and the other isn't, or if the other value is null.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.CompareToSignal(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary:
Compares the mathematical values of this object and another object, treating quiet NaN as signaling.
In this method, negative zero and positive zero are considered equal.
If this object or the other object is a quiet NaN or signaling NaN, this method will return a quiet NaN and will signal a FlagInvalid flag.
doc.param: A precision context. The precision, rounding, and exponent range are ignored. If HasFlags of the context is true, will store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: Quiet NaN if this object or the other object is NaN, or 0 if both objects have the same value, or -1 if this object is less than the other value, or 1 if this object is greater.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.CompareToWithContext(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary:
Compares the mathematical values of this object and another object.
In this method, negative zero and positive zero are considered equal.
If this object or the other object is a quiet NaN or signaling NaN, this method returns a quiet NaN, and will signal a FlagInvalid flag if either is a signaling NaN.
doc.param: A precision context. The precision, rounding, and exponent range are ignored. If HasFlags of the context is true, will store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: Quiet NaN if this object or the other object is NaN, or 0 if both objects have the same value, or -1 if this object is less than the other value, or 1 if this object is greater.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Create(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EInteger)
doc.summary: Creates a number with the value exponent*10^mantissa.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Create(System.Int32,System.Int32)
doc.summary: Creates a number with the value exponent*10^mantissa.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.CreateNaN(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger)
doc.summary: Creates a not-a-number arbitrary-precision decimal number.
doc.param: A number to use as diagnostic information associated with this object. If none is needed, should be zero.
doc.returns: A quiet not-a-number.
doc.exception: The parameter is null or is less than 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.CreateNaN(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Creates a not-a-number arbitrary-precision decimal number.
doc.param: A number to use as diagnostic information associated with this object. If none is needed, should be zero.
Whether the return value will be signaling (true) or quiet (false).
Whether the return value is negative.
A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number.
doc.exception: The parameter is null or is less than 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Divide(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal)
doc.summary: Divides this object by another decimal number and returns the result. When possible, the result will be exact.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two numbers. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Returns NaN if the result can't be exact because it would have a nonterminating decimal expansion.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Divide(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Divides this arbitrary-precision decimal number by another arbitrary-precision decimal number. The preferred exponent for the result is this object's exponent minus the divisor's exponent.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0; or, either is null or 's precision is 0, and the result would have a nonterminating decimal expansion; or, the rounding mode is Rounding.Unnecessary and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.DivideAndRemainderNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal)
doc.summary: Calculates the quotient and remainder using the DivideToIntegerNaturalScale and the formula in RemainderNaturalScale.
doc.returns: A 2 element array consisting of the quotient and remainder in that order.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.DivideAndRemainderNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Calculates the quotient and remainder using the DivideToIntegerNaturalScale and the formula in RemainderNaturalScale.
doc.param: A precision context object to control the precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. This context will be used only in the division portion of the remainder calculation; as a result, it's possible for the remainder to have a higher precision than given in this context. Flags will be set on the given context only if the context's HasFlags is true and the integer part of the division result doesn't fit the precision and exponent range without rounding.
doc.returns: A 2 element array consisting of the quotient and remainder in that order.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.DivideToExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Divides two arbitrary-precision decimal numbers, and gives a particular exponent to the result.
doc.param: The desired exponent. A negative number places the cutoff point to the right of the usual decimal point. A positive number places the cutoff point to the left of the usual decimal point.

A precision context object to control the rounding mode to use if the result must be scaled down to have the same exponent as this value. If the precision given in the context is other than 0, calls the Quantize method with both arguments equal to the result of the operation (and can signal FlagInvalid and return NaN if the result doesn't fit the given precision). If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the context defines an exponent range and the desired exponent is outside that range. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the rounding mode is Rounding.Unnecessary and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.DivideToExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary: Divides two arbitrary-precision decimal numbers, and gives a particular exponent to the result.
doc.param: The desired exponent. A negative number places the cutoff point to the right of the usual decimal point. A positive number places the cutoff point to the left of the usual decimal point.
The rounding mode to use if the result must be scaled down to have the same exponent as this value.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Returns NaN if the rounding mode is Rounding.Unnecessary and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.DivideToExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,System.Int64,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Divides two arbitrary-precision decimal numbers, and gives a particular exponent to the result.
doc.param: The desired exponent. A negative number places the cutoff point to the right of the usual decimal point. A positive number places the cutoff point to the left of the usual decimal point.

A precision context object to control the rounding mode to use if the result must be scaled down to have the same exponent as this value. If the precision given in the context is other than 0, calls the Quantize method with both arguments equal to the result of the operation (and can signal FlagInvalid and return NaN if the result doesn't fit the given precision). If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the context defines an exponent range and the desired exponent is outside that range. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the rounding mode is Rounding.Unnecessary and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.DivideToExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,System.Int64,PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary: Divides two arbitrary-precision decimal numbers, and gives a particular exponent to the result.
doc.param: The desired exponent. A negative number places the cutoff point to the right of the usual decimal point. A positive number places the cutoff point to the left of the usual decimal point.
The rounding mode to use if the result must be scaled down to have the same exponent as this value.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the rounding mode is Rounding.Unnecessary and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.DivideToIntegerNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal)
doc.summary: Divides two arbitrary-precision decimal numbers, and returns the integer part of the result, rounded down, with the preferred exponent set to this value's exponent minus the divisor's exponent.
doc.returns: The integer part of the quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.DivideToIntegerNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Divides this object by another object, and returns the integer part of the result, with the preferred exponent set to this value's exponent minus the divisor's exponent.
doc.param: A precision context object to control the precision, rounding, and exponent range of the integer part of the result. Flags will be set on the given context only if the context's HasFlags is true and the integer part of the result doesn't fit the precision and exponent range without rounding.
doc.returns: The integer part of the quotient of the two objects. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the return value would overflow the exponent range. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the rounding mode is Rounding.Unnecessary and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.DivideToIntegerZeroScale(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Divides this object by another object, and returns the integer part of the result, with the exponent set to 0.
doc.param: A precision context object to control the precision. The rounding and exponent range settings of this context are ignored. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: The integer part of the quotient of the two objects. The exponent will be set to 0. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0, or if the result doesn't fit the given precision.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.DivideToSameExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary: Divides this object by another decimal number and returns a result with the same exponent as this object (the dividend).
doc.param: The rounding mode to use if the result must be scaled down to have the same exponent as this value.
doc.returns: The quotient of the two numbers. Signals FlagDivideByZero and returns infinity if the divisor is 0 and the dividend is nonzero. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor and the dividend are 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the rounding mode is Rounding.Unnecessary and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Equals(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal)
doc.summary: Determines whether this object's mantissa and exponent are equal to those of another object.
doc.returns: True if this object's mantissa and exponent are equal to those of another object; otherwise, false.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Equals(System.Object)
doc.summary: Determines whether this object's mantissa and exponent are equal to those of another object and that other object is an arbitrary-precision decimal number.
doc.returns: True if the objects are equal; otherwise, false.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Exp(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds e (the base of natural logarithms) raised to the power of this object's value.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). This parameter cannot be null, as the exponential function's results are generally not exact.
doc.returns: Exponential of this object. If this object's value is 1, returns an approximation to " e" within the given precision. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0).

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Exponent
doc.summary: Gets this object's exponent. This object's value will be an integer if the exponent is positive or zero.
doc.value: This object's exponent. This object's value will be an integer if the exponent is positive or zero.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.FromBigInteger(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger)
doc.summary: Converts a big integer to an arbitrary precision decimal.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number with the exponent set to 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.FromDouble(System.Double)
doc.summary: Creates a decimal number from a 64-bit binary floating-point number. This method computes the exact value of the floating point number, not an approximation, as is often the case by converting the floating point number to a string first. Remember, though, that the exact value of a 64-bit binary floating-point number is not always the value that results when passing a literal decimal number (for example, calling ExtendedDecimal.FromDouble(0.1f) ), since not all decimal numbers can be converted to exact binary numbers (in the example given, the resulting arbitrary-precision decimal will be the value of the closest "double" to 0.1, not 0.1 exactly). To create an arbitrary-precision decimal number from a decimal number, use FromString instead in most cases (for example: ExtendedDecimal.FromString("0.1") ).
doc.returns: A decimal number with the same value as .

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.FromExtendedFloat(PeterO.Numbers.EFloat)
doc.summary: Creates a decimal number from an arbitrary-precision binary floating-point number.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.FromInt32(System.Int32)
doc.summary: Creates a decimal number from a 32-bit signed integer.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number with the exponent set to 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.FromInt64(System.Int64)
doc.summary: Creates a decimal number from a 64-bit signed integer.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number with the exponent set to 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.FromSingle(System.Single)
doc.summary: Creates a decimal number from a 32-bit binary floating-point number. This method computes the exact value of the floating point number, not an approximation, as is often the case by converting the floating point number to a string first. Remember, though, that the exact value of a 32-bit binary floating-point number is not always the value that results when passing a literal decimal number (for example, calling ExtendedDecimal.FromSingle(0.1f) ), since not all decimal numbers can be converted to exact binary numbers (in the example given, the resulting arbitrary-precision decimal will be the the value of the closest "float" to 0.1, not 0.1 exactly). To create an arbitrary-precision decimal number from a decimal number, use FromString instead in most cases (for example: ExtendedDecimal.FromString("0.1") ).
doc.returns: A decimal number with the same value as .

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.FromString(System.String)
doc.summary: Creates a decimal number from a string that represents a number. See FromString(String, int, int, EContext) for more information.
doc.param: A string that represents a number.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number with the same value as the given string.
doc.exception: The parameter is not a correctly formatted number string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.FromString(System.String,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Creates a decimal number from a string that represents a number. See FromString(String, int, int, EContext) for more information.
doc.param: A string that represents a number.

A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number with the same value as the given string.
doc.exception: The parameter is not a correctly formatted number string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.FromString(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
doc.summary: Creates a decimal number from a string that represents a number. See FromString(String, int, int, EContext) for more information.
doc.param: A string that represents a number.
A zero-based index showing where the desired portion of begins.
The length, in code units, of the desired portion of (but not more than 's length).
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number with the same value as the given string.
doc.exception: The parameter is not a correctly formatted number string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.FromString(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)

summary.para: Creates a decimal number from a string that represents a number.
The format of the string generally consists of:

list.item: An optional plus sign ("+" , U+002B) or minus sign ("-", U+002D) (if '-' , the value is negative.)
One or more digits, with a single optional decimal point after the first digit and before the last digit.
Optionally, "E+"/"e+" (positive exponent) or "E-"/"e-" (negative exponent) plus one or more digits specifying the exponent.

summary.para: The string can also be "-INF", "-Infinity", "Infinity", "INF" , quiet NaN ("NaN" /"-NaN") followed by any number of digits, or signaling NaN ("sNaN" /"-sNaN") followed by any number of digits, all in any combination of upper and lower case.

All characters mentioned above are the corresponding characters in the Basic Latin range. In particular, the digits must be the basic digits 0 to 9 (U+0030 to U+0039). The string is not allowed to contain white space characters, including spaces.

doc.param: A text string, a portion of which represents a number.
A zero-based index that identifies the start of the number.
The length of the number within the string.

A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number with the same value as the given string.
doc.exception: The parameter is not a correctly formatted number string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.GetHashCode
doc.summary: Calculates this object's hash code.
doc.returns: This object's hash code.

doc.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this object is not a number (NaN).
doc.returns: True if this object is not a number (NaN); otherwise, false.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.IsPositiveInfinity
doc.summary: Returns whether this object is positive infinity.

doc.returns: True if this object is a signaling not-a-number value; otherwise, false.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.IsZero

doc.value: True if this object's value equals 0; otherwise, false.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Log(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the natural logarithm of this object, that is, the power (exponent) that e (the base of natural logarithms) must be raised to in order to equal this object's value.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). This parameter cannot be null, as the ln function's results are generally not exact.
doc.returns: Ln(this object). Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns NaN if this object is less than 0 (the result would be a complex number with a real part equal to Ln of this object's absolute value and an imaginary part equal to pi, but the return value is still NaN.). Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0). Signals no flags and returns negative infinity if this object's value is 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Log10(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the base-10 logarithm of this object, that is, the power (exponent) that the number 10 must be raised to in order to equal this object's value.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). This parameter cannot be null, as the ln function's results are generally not exact.
doc.returns: Ln(this object)/Ln(10). Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if this object is less than 0. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0).

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Mantissa
doc.summary: Gets this object's un-scaled value.
doc.value: This object's un-scaled value. Will be negative if this object's value is negative (including a negative NaN).

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Multiply(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal)
doc.summary: Multiplies two decimal numbers. The resulting exponent will be the sum of the exponents of the two decimal numbers.
doc.returns: The product of the two decimal numbers.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Multiply(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Multiplies two decimal numbers. The resulting scale will be the sum of the scales of the two decimal numbers. The result's sign is positive if both operands have the same sign, and negative if they have different signs.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: The product of the two decimal numbers.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.NegativeInfinity

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.NextMinus(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the largest value that's smaller than the given value.
doc.param: A precision context object to control the precision and exponent range of the result. The rounding mode from this context is ignored. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
doc.returns: Returns the largest value that's less than the given value. Returns negative infinity if the result is negative infinity. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter is null, the precision is 0, or has an unlimited exponent range.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.NextPlus(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the smallest value that's greater than the given value.
doc.param: A precision context object to control the precision and exponent range of the result. The rounding mode from this context is ignored. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
doc.returns: Returns the smallest value that's greater than the given value.Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter is null, the precision is 0, or has an unlimited exponent range.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.NextToward(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the next value that is closer to the other object's value than this object's value. Returns a copy of this value with the same sign as the other value if both values are equal.
doc.param: A precision context object to control the precision and exponent range of the result. The rounding mode from this context is ignored. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
doc.returns: Returns the next value that is closer to the other object' s value than this object's value. Signals FlagInvalid and returns NaN if the parameter is null, the precision is 0, or has an unlimited exponent range.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.One
doc.summary: Represents the number 1.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.PI(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the constant π.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). This parameter cannot be null, as π can never be represented exactly.
doc.returns: π rounded to the given precision. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0).

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Plus(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Rounds this object's value to a given precision, using the given rounding mode and range of exponent, and also converts negative zero to positive zero.
doc.param: A context for controlling the precision, rounding mode, and exponent range. Can be null.
doc.returns: The closest value to this object's value, rounded to the specified precision. Returns the same value as this object if is null or the precision and exponent range are unlimited.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.PositiveInfinity
doc.summary: Positive infinity, greater than any other number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Pow(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Raises this object's value to the given exponent.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
doc.returns: This^exponent. Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns NaN if this object and exponent are both 0; or if this value is less than 0 and the exponent either has a fractional part or is infinity. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0), and the exponent has a fractional part.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Pow(System.Int32)
doc.summary: Raises this object's value to the given exponent.
doc.returns: This^exponent. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if this object and exponent are both 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Pow(System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Raises this object's value to the given exponent.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags).
doc.returns: This^exponent. Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns NaN if this object and exponent are both 0.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Precision
doc.summary: Finds the number of digits in this number's mantissa. Returns 1 if this value is 0, and 0 if this value is infinity or NaN.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Quantize(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary:
Returns a decimal number with the same value as this object but with the same exponent as another decimal number.
Note that this is not always the same as rounding to a given number of decimal places, since it can fail if the difference between this value's exponent and the desired exponent is too big, depending on the maximum precision. If rounding to a number of decimal places is desired, it's better to use the RoundToExponent and RoundToIntegral methods instead.
Remark: This method can be used to implement fixed-point decimal arithmetic, in which a fixed number of digits come after the decimal point. A fixed-point decimal arithmetic in which no digits come after the decimal point (a desired exponent of 0) is considered an "integer arithmetic".
doc.param: A decimal number containing the desired exponent of the result. The mantissa is ignored. The exponent is the number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

A precision context to control precision and rounding of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A decimal number with the same value as this object but with the exponent changed. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the result can't fit the given precision without rounding, or if the precision context defines an exponent range and the given exponent is outside that range.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Quantize(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.param: The desired exponent for the result. The exponent is the number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

A precision context to control precision and rounding of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A decimal number with the same value as this object but with the exponent changed. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if this object is infinity, if the rounded result can't fit the given precision, or if the context defines an exponent range and the given exponent is outside that range.

Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Quantize(System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.ERounding)
doc.summary:
Returns a decimal number with the same value as this one but a new exponent.
Remark: This method can be used to implement fixed-point decimal arithmetic, in which a fixed number of digits come after the decimal point. A fixed-point decimal arithmetic in which no digits come after the decimal point (a desired exponent of 0) is considered an "integer arithmetic".
doc.param: The desired exponent for the result. The exponent is the number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.
A rounding mode to use in case the result needs to be rounded to fit the given exponent.
doc.returns: A decimal number with the same value as this object but with the exponent changed. Returns not-a-number (NaN) if this object is infinity, or if the rounding mode is ERounding.None and the result is not exact.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Reduce(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary:
Removes trailing zeros from this object's mantissa. For example, 1.00 becomes 1.
If this object's value is 0, changes the exponent to 0.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: This value with trailing zeros removed. Note that if the result has a very high exponent and the context says to clamp high exponents, there may still be some trailing zeros in the mantissa.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Remainder(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the remainder that results when dividing two arbitrary-precision decimal numbers.
doc.param: The parameter is not documented yet.
doc.returns: The remainder of the two objects.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RemainderNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal)
doc.summary: Calculates the remainder of a number by the formula "this" - (("this" / "divisor") * "divisor").
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RemainderNaturalScale(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Calculates the remainder of a number by the formula "this" - (("this" / "divisor") * "divisor").
doc.param: A precision context object to control the precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. This context will be used only in the division portion of the remainder calculation; as a result, it's possible for the return value to have a higher precision than given in this context. Flags will be set on the given context only if the context's HasFlags is true and the integer part of the division result doesn't fit the precision and exponent range without rounding.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RemainderNear(PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary:
Finds the distance to the closest multiple of the given divisor, based on the result of dividing this object's value by another object's value.
If this and the other object divide evenly, the result is 0.
If the remainder's absolute value is less than half of the divisor's absolute value, the result has the same sign as this object and will be the distance to the closest multiple.
If the remainder's absolute value is more than half of the divisor' s absolute value, the result has the opposite sign of this object and will be the distance to the closest multiple.
If the remainder's absolute value is exactly half of the divisor's absolute value, the result has the opposite sign of this object if the quotient, rounded down, is odd, and has the same sign as this object if the quotient, rounded down, is even, and the result's absolute value is half of the divisor's absolute value. This function is also known as the "IEEE Remainder" function.
doc.param: A precision context object to control the precision. The rounding and exponent range settings of this context are ignored (the rounding mode is always treated as HalfEven). If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null.
doc.returns: The distance of the closest multiple. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the divisor is 0, or either the result of integer division (the quotient) or the remainder wouldn't fit the given precision.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RoundToBinaryPrecision(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Rounds this object's value to a given maximum bit length, using the given rounding mode and range of exponent.
doc.param: A context for controlling the precision, rounding mode, and exponent range. The precision is interpreted as the maximum bit length of the mantissa. Can be null.
doc.returns: The closest value to this object's value, rounded to the specified precision. Returns the same value as this object if is null or the precision and exponent range are unlimited.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RoundToExponent(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a decimal number with the same value as this object but rounded to a new exponent if necessary.
doc.param: The minimum exponent the result can have. This is the maximum number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A decimal number rounded to the closest value representable in the given precision, meaning if the result can't fit the precision, additional digits are discarded to make it fit. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the precision context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to the given exponent when rounding, and the given exponent is outside of the valid range of the precision context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RoundToExponent(System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a decimal number with the same value as this object but rounded to a new exponent if necessary.
doc.param: The minimum exponent the result can have. This is the maximum number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.

A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A decimal number rounded to the closest value representable in the given precision, meaning if the result can't fit the precision, additional digits are discarded to make it fit. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the precision context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to the given exponent when rounding, and the given exponent is outside of the valid range of the precision context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RoundToExponentExact(PeterO.Numbers.EInteger,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a decimal number with the same value as this object but rounded to an integer, and signals an invalid operation if the result would be inexact.
doc.param: The minimum exponent the result can have. This is the maximum number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.
A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.
doc.returns: A decimal number rounded to the closest value representable in the given precision. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the result can't fit the given precision without rounding. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the precision context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to the given exponent when rounding, and the given exponent is outside of the valid range of the precision context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RoundToExponentExact(System.Int32,PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a decimal number with the same value as this object but rounded to an integer, and signals an invalid operation if the result would be inexact.
doc.param: The minimum exponent the result can have. This is the maximum number of fractional digits in the result, expressed as a negative number. Can also be positive, which eliminates lower-order places from the number. For example, -3 means round to the thousandth (10^-3, 0.0001), and 3 means round to the thousand (10^3, 1000). A value of 0 rounds the number to an integer.
A context object for arbitrary-precision arithmetic settings.
doc.returns: A decimal number rounded to the closest value representable in the given precision. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the result can't fit the given precision without rounding. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the precision context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to the given exponent when rounding, and the given exponent is outside of the valid range of the precision context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RoundToIntegralExact(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a decimal number with the same value as this object but rounded to an integer, and signals an invalid operation if the result would be inexact.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision and rounding of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A decimal number rounded to the closest integer representable in the given precision. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the result can't fit the given precision without rounding. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the precision context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to 0 when rounding, and 0 is outside of the valid range of the precision context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RoundToIntegralNoRoundedFlag(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Returns a decimal number with the same value as this object but rounded to an integer, without adding the FlagInexact or FlagRounded flags.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision and rounding of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags), except that this function will never add the FlagRounded and FlagInexact flags (the only difference between this and RoundToExponentExact). Can be null, in which case the default rounding mode is HalfEven.
doc.returns: A decimal number rounded to the closest integer representable in the given precision, meaning if the result can't fit the precision, additional digits are discarded to make it fit. Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the precision context defines an exponent range, the new exponent must be changed to 0 when rounding, and 0 is outside of the valid range of the precision context.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.RoundToPrecision(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Rounds this object's value to a given precision, using the given rounding mode and range of exponent.
doc.param: A context for controlling the precision, rounding mode, and exponent range. Can be null.
doc.returns: The closest value to this object's value, rounded to the specified precision. Returns the same value as this object if is null or the precision and exponent range are unlimited.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.SquareRoot(PeterO.Numbers.EContext)
doc.summary: Finds the square root of this object's value.
doc.param: A precision context to control precision, rounding, and exponent range of the result. If HasFlags of the context is true, will also store the flags resulting from the operation (the flags are in addition to the pre-existing flags). This parameter cannot be null, as the square root function's results are generally not exact for many inputs.
doc.returns: The square root. Signals the flag FlagInvalid and returns NaN if this object is less than 0 (the square root would be a complex number, but the return value is still NaN). Signals FlagInvalid and returns not-a-number (NaN) if the parameter is null or the precision is unlimited (the context's Precision property is 0).

doc.summary: Represents the number 10.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.ToBigInteger
doc.summary: Converts this value to an arbitrary-precision integer. Any fractional part in this value will be discarded when converting to a big integer.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision integer.
doc.exception: This object's value is infinity or NaN.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.ToBigIntegerExact
doc.summary: Converts this value to an arbitrary-precision integer, checking whether the fractional part of the integer would be lost.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision integer.
doc.exception: This object's value is infinity or NaN.
This object's value is not an exact integer.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.ToDouble
doc.summary:
Converts this value to a 64-bit floating-point number. The half-even rounding mode is used.
If this value is a NaN, sets the high bit of the 64-bit floating point number's mantissa for a quiet NaN, and clears it for a signaling NaN. Then the next highest bit of the mantissa is cleared for a quiet NaN, and set for a signaling NaN. Then the other bits of the mantissa are set to the lowest bits of this object's unsigned mantissa.
doc.returns: The closest 64-bit floating-point number to this value. The return value can be positive infinity or negative infinity if this value exceeds the range of a 64-bit floating point number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.ToEngineeringString
doc.summary: Same as toString(), except that when an exponent is used it will be a multiple of 3.
doc.returns: A text string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.ToExtendedFloat
doc.summary: Creates a binary floating-point number from this object's value. Note that if the binary floating-point number contains a negative exponent, the resulting value might not be exact. However, the resulting binary float will contain enough precision to accurately convert it to a 32-bit or 64-bit floating point number (float or double).
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision binary float.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.ToPlainString
doc.summary: Converts this value to a string, but without using exponential notation.
doc.returns: A text string.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.ToSingle
doc.summary:
Converts this value to a 32-bit floating-point number. The half-even rounding mode is used.
If this value is a NaN, sets the high bit of the 32-bit floating point number's mantissa for a quiet NaN, and clears it for a signaling NaN. Then the next highest bit of the mantissa is cleared for a quiet NaN, and set for a signaling NaN. Then the other bits of the mantissa are set to the lowest bits of this object's unsigned mantissa.
doc.returns: The closest 32-bit floating-point number to this value. The return value can be positive infinity or negative infinity if this value exceeds the range of a 32-bit floating point number.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.ToString
doc.summary: Converts this value to a string. Returns a value compatible with this class's FromString method.
doc.returns: A string representation of this object.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Ulp
doc.summary: Returns the unit in the last place. The mantissa will be 1 and the exponent will be this number's exponent. Returns 1 with an exponent of 0 if this number is infinity or NaN.
doc.returns: An arbitrary-precision decimal number.

doc.name: P:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.UnsignedMantissa
doc.summary: Gets the absolute value of this object's un-scaled value.
doc.value: The absolute value of this object's un-scaled value.

doc.name: F:PeterO.Numbers.EDecimal.Zero
doc.summary: Represents the number 0.

doc.name: T:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat
doc.summary:
Represents an arbitrary-precision binary floating-point number. Consists of an integer mantissa and an integer exponent, both arbitrary-precision. The value of the number equals mantissa * 2^exponent. This class also supports values for negative zero, not-a-number (NaN) values, and infinity.
Passing a signaling NaN to any arithmetic operation shown here will signal the flag FlagInvalid and return a quiet NaN, even if another operand to that operation is a quiet NaN, unless noted otherwise.
Passing a quiet NaN to any arithmetic operation shown here will return a quiet NaN, unless noted otherwise.
Unless noted otherwise, passing a null arbitrary-precision binary float argument to any method here will throw an exception.
When an arithmetic operation signals the flag FlagInvalid, FlagOverflow, or FlagDivideByZero, it will not throw an exception too, unless the operation's trap is enabled in the precision context (see PrecisionContext's Traps property).
An arbitrary-precision binary float value can be serialized in one of the following ways:
By calling the toString() method. However, not all strings can be converted back to an arbitrary-precision binary float without loss, especially if the string has a fractional part.
By calling the UnsignedMantissa, Exponent, and IsNegative properties, and calling the IsInfinity, IsQuietNaN, and IsSignalingNaN methods. The return values combined will uniquely identify a particular arbitrary-precision binary float value.
If an operation requires creating an intermediate value that might be too big to fit in memory (or might require more than 2 gigabytes of memory to store -- due to the current use of a 32-bit integer internally as a length), the operation may signal an invalid-operation flag and return not-a-number (NaN). In certain rare cases, the CompareTo method may throw OutOfMemoryException (called OutOfMemoryError in Java) in the same circumstances.
Thread safety
Instances of this class are immutable, so they are inherently safe for use by multiple threads. Multiple instances of this object with the same properties are interchangeable, so they should not be compared using the "==" operator (which only checks if each side of the operator is the same instance).
Comparison considerations
This class's natural ordering (under the CompareTo method) is not consistent with the Equals method. This means that two values that compare as equal under the CompareTo method might not be equal under the Equals method. The CompareTo method compares the mathematical values of the two instances passed to it (and considers two different NaN values as equal), while two instances with the same mathematical value, but different exponents, will be considered unequal under the Equals method.

doc.name: M:PeterO.Numbers.EFloat.Abs
